title: TEOTFW is a f***ing masterpiece
content:
> "People can't be answers. They're just more questions."

I usually don't get this obsessed with a lot of shows. The show has to bend the film making rules really badly for it to be eligible to hit the spot. The End of the F***ing World is one of those shows. 

I love it, not because it's relatable or that I resonate with the themes that are highlighted in the series but because I genuinely think it's one of the best shows objectively. It has the right amount of experimentation done in the right way. It's an experience and it's done better in this medium (as opposed to the book). There's no centralised message (or not one that I could gather) but a string of realisations throughout the show that makes you feel like you've actually learnt something. 

A lot of stuff happens in a very short time. Everything in this show is rushed but that is not necessarily a bad thing. The fact that the show treats big plot twists as ordinary story devices is a good thing in its own way. You never get disappointed and the show has to do an even better job to top what had already been the best scene till that point. 

The storytelling is done right. The colours are beautiful. The jump cuts make sense. It really feels like a lot of work was done before actually releasing it. The comedy is done right visually as well as narratively.

This show goes on for just about 2 hours 40 minutes, the average size of a film split into 8 episodes (which is a unique decision as well) shows it in a way that is so creatively unique and aesthetic. The show starts almost like a satire. That's what I thought in the beginning and I'm pretty sure the book was intended to be a satire too (I haven't read the book yet) but on completing season 1, it became apparent how the inhumane nature of the characters at the beginning of the series was just "teenagers being teenagers" and to make the end character development even more interesting and drastic while being accurate.

- Spoiler Alert

    James, an introvert who has shut his feelings off ever since his mom committed suicide in front of him and Alyssa, an extrovert who never really got the attention from both her parents from a very young age. Her dad left her and her mom was too caught up with bringing her life together. 

The soundtrack is indescribable. It matches the tone of the show perfectly. I watched the show around 2 years back and I still listen to the soundtrack to this day. I think it's genius how they use calm songs during morbid scenes. It really confuses the audience and bends our perspective on how we perceive a particular scene. You're confused if you should be sickened by the gore they're showing in the frame or if you should enjoy the song playing in the background. 

The episodic nature allows there to be cliffhangers even if the total story is the size of one movie. There are so many 4th wall breaks and foreshadowing which just goes on to show how this is nothing like the typical Netflix cliches. The costumes are very well done as well. (Especially Alyssa's wedding dress and James's funeral clothes in S2. The contrasting effect is prevalent here too!)

The characters are likable and their behaviour seems justified even if it's erratic. The actors did a wonderful job playing teenagers while actually being almost a decade older their characters.

All in all, I'm very glad that this show turned out like how it is right now. No one could have done it better. The more I say about this series, the more I feel like I'm not appreciating it enough. I say my thanks to the directors, writers, producers, actors, art directors, cinematographers, casting directors, costume designers and everyone who made this show a reality.
description: "People can't be answers. They're just more questions."

title: CoDiff
content:
CoDiff is a VSCode extension that has live access to all your teammates' local changes, greatly improving communication: it notifies you of conflicts with teammates as they occur. Download the extension from [here](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=bar9.codiff).

## Features
- Use your GitHub account to log in.
- Start conflict detection on any git initialized repository.
- Get notified when another user saves the same file that you are working on.
- Whenever you save a particular file you will be notified if you conflict with a previously saved local version.
- View conflicts between your version and the saved version of one of the collaborators.
- Receive notification asking you to pull changes if your local version is behind some commits compared to the one on GitHub.
- Access the sidebar from where you can start conflict detection and view other details regarding the room you are in which includes the room ID, git repo url, branch and revision ID.

## Screenshots
![](https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/706928005313855620/846836626683330570/unknown.png?width=379&height=90)

Conflict notification

![](https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/706928005313855620/846837133045792776/unknown.png?width=363&height=34)

File saving notification

![](https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/706928005313855620/846837601574060032/unknown.png?width=641&height=350)

Viewing conflicts
description: This was a freelancing project for Roland Brand on which me and Anshul worked on for over 2 months. The difficult part was understaning the functioning of scm extensions.

title: COVICoin
content:
> "People can't be answers. They're just more questions."

I usually don't get this obsessed with a lot of shows. The show has to bend the film making rules really badly for it to be eligible to hit the spot. The End of the F***ing World is one of those shows. 

I love it, not because it's relatable or that I resonate with the themes that are highlighted in the series but because I genuinely think it's one of the best shows objectively. It has the right amount of experimentation done in the right way. It's an experience and it's done better in this medium (as opposed to the book). There's no centralised message (or not one that I could gather) but a string of realisations throughout the show that makes you feel like you've actually learnt something. 

A lot of stuff happens in a very short time. Everything in this show is rushed but that is not necessarily a bad thing. The fact that the show treats big plot twists as ordinary story devices is a good thing in its own way. You never get disappointed and the show has to do an even better job to top what had already been the best scene till that point. 

The storytelling is done right. The colours are beautiful. The jump cuts make sense. It really feels like a lot of work was done before actually releasing it. The comedy is done right visually as well as narratively.

This show goes on for just about 2 hours 40 minutes, the average size of a film split into 8 episodes (which is a unique decision as well) shows it in a way that is so creatively unique and aesthetic. The show starts almost like a satire. That's what I thought in the beginning and I'm pretty sure the book was intended to be a satire too (I haven't read the book yet) but on completing season 1, it became apparent how the inhumane nature of the characters at the beginning of the series was just "teenagers being teenagers" and to make the end character development even more interesting and drastic while being accurate.

- Spoiler Alert

    James, an introvert who has shut his feelings off ever since his mom committed suicide in front of him and Alyssa, an extrovert who never really got the attention from both her parents from a very young age. Her dad left her and her mom was too caught up with bringing her life together. 

The soundtrack is indescribable. It matches the tone of the show perfectly. I watched the show around 2 years back and I still listen to the soundtrack to this day. I think it's genius how they use calm songs during morbid scenes. It really confuses the audience and bends our perspective on how we perceive a particular scene. You're confused if you should be sickened by the gore they're showing in the frame or if you should enjoy the song playing in the background. 

The episodic nature allows there to be cliffhangers even if the total story is the size of one movie. There are so many 4th wall breaks and foreshadowing which just goes on to show how this is nothing like the typical Netflix cliches. The costumes are very well done as well. (Especially Alyssa's wedding dress and James's funeral clothes in S2. The contrasting effect is prevalent here too!)

The characters are likable and their behaviour seems justified even if it's erratic. The actors did a wonderful job playing teenagers while actually being almost a decade older their characters.

All in all, I'm very glad that this show turned out like how it is right now. No one could have done it better. The more I say about this series, the more I feel like I'm not appreciating it enough. I say my thanks to the directors, writers, producers, actors, art directors, cinematographers, casting directors, costume designers and everyone who made this show a reality.
description: This project won the 2nd prize at FrostHack 2021 organized by Indian Institute of Technology, Mandi. I built this with my team members Anshul (backend) and Samvrant (designer).
